I'm a fan of SpaceX, but the fact that Tim felt the need to "remind" people that this had nothing to do with the launch of DM-2, which was scheduled for the following day, suggests that Elon and SpaceX were not thinking clearly when they decided to continue test firing just before the most important launch in their history :) .

 On Wednesday, Elon told CBS that the safety of getting the astronauts to ISS with DM-2 is, “the absolute priority. In fact, I’ve told the SpaceX team is not — it is not simply the top priority. It is the only priority.”

 Well then, how does your company's "only priority" now involve the explosion of a fueled SN4? Sure, there's zero connection between what's happening in Texas and what's happening at 39A, but it is an unwelcome distraction to blow up a SpaceX space ship just 25 hours before the public watches 2 American astronauts board another SpaceX space ship.

 It won't matter one iota once DM-2 is safely at the ISS, but this distraction could likely have been avoided by simply postponing fueled SN4 tests until next week and instead focusing on SN5 or 6.

 Yes, I'm aware that SpaceX has only certain dates and times in which to do specific testing, but discretion is often the better part of valor when you run a company that depends upon both public perception and political whims, at least for now.

 This also isn't just about Public Relations. Elon and his team have undoubtedly been nervous for the past couple of weeks as DM-2 approached. It's even possible that Elon and other team members have missed a fair amount of sleep this week. Well, how well do you think they are sleeping on this Friday night before the next potential DM-2 launch with the fresh image of SN4 become an instant fireball in their heads? It's almost certain that Chief Engineer Elon was watching the test. Delaying SN4 tests would have avoided this potential stress.

There was nothing wrong with SN4, the issue was unfortunately with the test stand fuel lines. It looks like one of the fuel lines on the test stand ruptured, started pouring fuel out onto the pad, it then got ignited by the heat of the engine and combusted. SN4 still attached to the test stand was forced upward into the simulated nosecone mass which ruptured the upper tank and blew that up as well.
The fuel from the ground storage tank continued to leak and maintained combustion for some time after.
Secondary explosions from smaller tanks that were attached to SN4.
Let's hope the overall damage to the test area is minimal as we have SN5 ready to go as soon as another test stand can be ready. If SN4 is anything to go by then SN5 should be capable of static fires without issue.

So it looks like the ground services is where the spark/explosion started, then went under the ship. Can't be certain, but it seems the methane was all up under the ship due to a leak from ground services. In any event, after the explosion starts, the ship 'jumps' upwards as evidenced by the exterior circumference going up... but the mass at the top did not move with it. This seems to have caused a stress overload at the top of the LOX tank, and it failed... right at the mass. The mass now has a lot of pressure to push it up and away. The resulting pressurized LOX being forced out the new exit on top is clearly evident, and causes SN4 to have a negative trajectory instead of 'launching', as it were, like SN1 did.. This in turn seems to rupture the Methane tank, which then shoots methane up into the LOX tank, which makes things even worse as the subject topples over.
